TIME 1250. 
EXPECT AN ILS APPROACH
ARRIVALS RUNWAY 08 RIGHT, DEPARTURES RUNWAY 08 LEFT.
TRANSITION ALTITUDE 4000 FT.
WORK IN PROGRESS ON APRON TWO.
SURFACE WIND 250, 14 KNOTS.
VISIBILITY 10 KILOMETRES OR MORE.
SCATTERED 2400 FT, BROKEN 4600 FT.
CUMULONIMBUS DETECTED.
TEMPERATURE +19, DEW POINT +4.
QNH 1007.
NO SIGNIFICANT CHANGE.
ACKNOWLEDGE RECEIPT OF INFORMATION OSCAR WITH APP ON 119.415.
DEPARTURE WITH DELIVERY ON 121.955."

wind direction 210 degrees true and speed of 10 statute miles per hour.
wind direction 210 degrees magnetic and speed of 10 knots.

bjvr5xv1.question:
Which of the following correctly translates data from the METAR of Lisbon aerodrome given below?
LPPT 150505Z 11006KT 9999 BKN016 M09/M16 Q1006 NOSIG =

options.text: Report time is 05:05 UTC, dew point is minus 16°C, QNH is 1006 hPa
Temperature is 16 degrees below ISA, visibility is at least 10 km, QNH is 1006 hPa
Wind comes from 110 degrees true, QNH is 9 hPa less than ISA, no significant changes forecast
The temperature is minus 9°C, report time is 15:05 PM, clouds are 5-7/8 at 1 600 ft

vaeARrHx.question:
Before departure you have been informed of changing weather conditions at the destination airport.
During the flight in the cruise, with approximately 500 nm to go, you want to check the destination weather. This information could be obtained through...

options.text: D-ATIS by using Satcom and data link equipment such as ACARS.
ATIS using the designated frequency of an airport en-route, on Very High Frequencies (VHF).
the scheduled VOLMET on Super High Frequencies (SHF).

o0x9H7xc.question:
Which answer decodes the following METAR correctly?
CYWG **172000Z** **30015G25KT** 3/4SM R36/**4000FT**/D 00/M02 BLSN BKN008 QNH **1020**

options.text: ...time 20:00 UTC, wind (true) 300°/15 kt, gusts max 25 kt, visibility 3/4 statute miles, RVR runway 36 4 000 ft (decreasing tendency), blowing snow, clouds broken at 800 ft, QNH 1 020 hPa
...time 20:00 UTC, wind (magnetic) 300°/15 kt, gusts max 25 kt, visibility 3/4 statute miles, RVR runway 36 4 000 m (from taxiway D), blowing snow, clouds broken at 8 000 ft, QNH 1 020 hPa
...time 20:00 LMT, wind (magnetic ) 300°/15 kt, gusts min 25 kt, visibility 3/4 statute miles, RVR runway 36 4 000 ft (decreasing tendency), blowing snow, clouds broken at 800 ft, QNH 1 020 hPa
...time 17:20 UTC, wind (true) 300°/15 kt, gusts max 25 kt, visibility 3/4 statute miles, RVR runway 36 4 000 ft, blowing snow, clouds broken at 800 m
Meteorological information for aircraft in flight.
A device used for measuring cloud base.

LPfuh1lk.question: When the term "CAVOK" is used in an aviation routine weather report (METAR), what are the values of visibility and cloud?

options.text: Visibility 10 km or more, no cloud below 5000 feet.
Visibility more than 5000 m, no cloud below 1500 m.
Visibility 10 km or more, no cloud below 1500 feet.
Visibility more than 8 km, no cloud below 3000 feet.

TQkDDL5k.question: An aircraft that encounters certain meteorological phenomena in flight must make a special report. Which of the following must be reported?

options.text: A heavy sandstorm seen some distance from track.
Light turbulence experienced by the aircraft.
Light icing experienced by the aircraft.
An isolated thunderstorm seen close to track.

7LukK7So.question:
Information about an aerodrome with an ATIS is also included in the list of VOLMET reports
The QNH is transmitted in

options.text: both the ATIS and the VOLMET reports.
neither the ATIS nor the VOLMET report.

rOHdFyQ8.question: What does ATIS mean and what can a pilot expect from it?

options.text: Automatic Terminal Information Service; it provides the pilot with information about weather, runway in use and approach type to be expected.
Aerodrome Traffic Indication Service; it provides the pilot with information on when other aircraft are expected to take off or land.
Airborne Traffic Information Service; it provides the pilot with information on other traffic in the vicinity.
Aerodrome Terminal Instruction Service; it provides the pilot with routings for instrument approach procedures.

Before departure the pilot is informed of changing weather conditions at the destination airport. 
 During the flight in the cruise, with approximately 500 NM to go, the pilot wishes to check the destination weather. Where/how could this information be obtained?

options.text: D-ATIS by using Satcom and data link equipment such as ACARS.
The scheduled VOLMET on Super High Frequencies (SHF).
ATIS using the designated frequency of an airport en-route, on Very High Frequencies (VHF).

options.text: Aviation routine weather reports (METAR) of specific airports

LRQmNeba.question: Aircraft in flight may receive weather information from several sources. Which of the following is correct?

options.text: VOLMET broadcasts recent METAR and SPECI reports for a group of aerodromes.
Any thunderstorms seen by another aircraft in flight will be subject to a special report.
ATIS broadcasts the TAF and METAR for the aerodrome which transmits it.
An ATS unit cannot provide aerodrome forecasts as part of a Flight Information Service.

TAeHcvTK.question: An aircraft is flying at a cruise altitude of 9 000 ft and at a distance of about 100 nm from its destination the pilot wants to listen to the ATIS. The message is very distorted and only parts of it can be received. What should the pilot do in order to have better reception?

options.text: Fly at a higher altitude to increase the range of the reception.
Increase the volume of the receiver.
Increase the volume of his/her headset.
Select the frequency of APPROACH because they are responsible for the higher airspace.

M7QAodnn.question: An aircraft is flying at a cruise altitude of 900 ft. At a distance of about 100 nm from its destination the pilot wants to listen to the ATIS. The message is very distorted and only parts of it can be received. In order to have better reception, the pilot should...

options.text: fly at a higher altitude to increase the range of the reception.
increase the volume of the receiver.
select the frequency of APPROACH because they are responsible for the higher airspace.
increase the volume of his/her headset.
recent METAR and SPECI reports from a published selection of aerodromes.
an area forecast for flights in the FIR below 5000 ft AGL.
recently received routine and special reports from aircraft within the FIR.
the latest TAFs and METARs for major international aerodromes.
